Graphical abstract We developed a series of high-loading Co-Al2O3-SiO2 catalysts to enhance the hydrogenation of N-propylcarbazole (NPCZ) by fine-tuning the Al/Si ratio. Our research reveals that adjusting this ratio can significantly modify the electronic structure of Co nanoparticles, as confirmed by XPS, H2-TPD, and CO-DRIFT analyses, thereby affecting the adsorption of hydrogen species and their interaction with unsaturated π-bonds of NPCZ intermediates. Optimal Al concentration promotes Co nanoparticles dispersion, while excessive Al leads to increased acidity and reduced surface area. The Co70/Al4Si1O catalyst, with an Al/Si ratio of 4, demonstrated superior hydrogenation efficiency by enabling fast and stable hydrogenation of NPCZ, achieving an activation energy of 64.53 kJ/mol and maintaining high performance over 10 cycles. Through DFT calculations, we explored the d-band center and Bader charge across 6 different Co10/Al-Si-O models and assessed the adsorption energies of NPCZ intermediates, along with the energetics of three stepwise reactions. The initial hydrogenation step from NPCZ to 4H-NPCZ is predominantly influenced by the catalyst's acidity/basicity, whereas the subsequent deeper hydrogenation steps of 4H-NPCZ and 8H-NPCZ are governed by the d-π feedback interaction between the metal and the adsorbate. This research offers critical guidance on selecting optimal supports for Co-based catalysts in LOHC hydrogenation. Keywords Co-based catalysts Metal-carrier interaction Liquid organic hydrogen carriers Supported catalysts Catalytic hydrogenation Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction The rapid growth of technology and globalization has fueled a substantial increase in the demand for energy fuels, driven by human activities and rapid industrialization. However, this heavy reliance on fossil fuels, such as coal and petroleum, not only raises concerns about their depleting reserves but also exacerbates environmental worries due to the emissions produced during combustion. Consequently, addressing energy security and environmental preservation has become a paramount global priority [1,2]. In response, renewable energy has garnered significant attention from both academia and industry, thanks to its environmentally friendly impact and long-term sustainability potential. Among the various renewable energy sources, hydrogen stands out as an essential candidate for spearheading future energy paradigms due to its unique characteristic of releasing only water upon combustion, free from any harmful emissions [3–5]. Hydrogen, despite its numerous advantages, faces challenges related to its flammability, explosiveness, and storage and transportation, particularly in liquefied form. To overcome these obstacles, various strategies for hydrogen storage have been proposed. Among these options, liquid organic hydrogen carriers (LOHCs) have shown promise in safely storing hydrogen under ambient conditions [6]. In 2002, Hansong Cheng et al. first demonstrated that heteroatom introduction into aromatic compounds significantly lowers dehydrogenation temperature. N-ethylcarbazole (NECZ) was found to achieve full dehydrogenation below 200 °C. Subsequently, a range of high-density and low dehydrogenation LOHCs were proposed [7], including the carbazole series [8–10], indole series [11,12], dibenzyltoluene [13,14] and acridine [15]. However, N-propylcarbazole (NPCZ) is a nitrogen-fused heterocyclic organic molecule (209 g/mol) with a melting point of 48 °C and boiling point of 361 °C. NPCZ exhibits a hydrogen storage density of 5.4 wt%, close to the 2025 US Department of Energy target (5.5 wt%). Compared to NECZ, NPCZ shows faster catalytic dehydrogenation kinetics and milder reaction conditions, making it a promising LOHC candidate. Notably, the effectiveness of hydrogenation in LOHCs heavily relies on the choice of catalyst. While precious metal-based catalysts, such as Ru, Rh, Pt, and Pd, have demonstrated excellent efficiency in hydrogenation reactions [16–19], their high cost limits their widespread application. As a result, non-precious metal catalysts have garnered increasing attention. Among these alternatives, cobalt (Co) catalysts have shown notable catalytic activity and distinctive properties in various reactions, including Fischer-Tropsch synthesis, hydrodesulfurization, and hydrodenitrogenation [20–22]. However, limited research has been conducted on their utilization in LOHC applications. Xue et al. introduced a Rh1Co/γ-Al2O3 bimetallic catalyst, which exhibited a 100 % hydrogen uptake for LOHCs at 90 °C, highlighting the unique electronic reactivity of cobalt-based catalysts [23]. The dispersion of the metal and its strong interaction with the support are crucial factors influencing catalytic reactions. In cobalt-based catalysts, smaller metal particle sizes have been found to possess higher hydrogen transfer capacity compared to larger ones [24]. Wang et al. emphasized that the size of cobalt particles is determined by the pore size of the supporting material, which provides additional active sites for the reaction and ensures a uniform distribution of the metal within a specific range [25]. This uniformity is essential, as specific structural features of nanoparticles, such as steps, edges, and corners, can significantly impact both catalytic activity and selectivity [26]. Supporting materials play a crucial role in catalytic reactions, providing high specific surface areas, thermal stability, and intricate pore structures. However, singular supports often have limitations in terms of configuration and quantity of adsorption sites, as well as acidity strength and other attributes. To overcome these constraints, researchers have explored the synthesis of composite carriers that incorporate additional elements to meet diverse performance requirements. In a study by Gao et al., Ni was deposited onto CeO2-ZrO2/SiO2 composite supports and utilized in the methane autothermal reforming (MATR) reaction [27]. By carefully adjusting the Ce to Zr ratio, the intrinsic benefits of CeO2, ZrO2, and SiO2 were effectively combined. This composite support exhibited an increased specific surface area and improved dispersion of nickel on the catalyst. Additionally, the incorporation of ZrO2 enhanced the mobility of hydrogen atoms, increased the reducibility of nickel, and amplified the acid-base sites on the catalyst surface, facilitating the adsorption and activation of methane. Incorporating SiO2 into the Al2O3 framework is a useful strategy to enhance the specific surface area of the carrier and establish stable acid centers. The acidity of the support plays a crucial role in the adsorption and desorption of reactants and products, with an optimal acidic site being favorable for catalytic processes. Jeong et al. discovered that Ni/MSA (mesoporous SiO2-Al2O3) demonstrated high activity for hydrogen storage in aromatic LOHC compounds [28]. This remarkable activity can be attributed to the proximity of Ni species on MSA to Brønsted acidic sites, facilitating H2 spillover and enhancing catalytic efficiency. Sun et al. improved the Co/Al2O3 catalyst by incorporating a small amount of SiO2 using the impregnation method [29]. This addition significantly enhanced the Fischer-Tropsch synthesis activity. The improvement can be attributed to the alteration of electron transfer dynamics between the support and SiO2, leading to enhanced Co reduction. Furthermore, the modified catalyst exhibited enhanced bridge-type CO adsorption, promoting the CO reaction. Optimal CO conversion was achieved with a Si addition of 10 wt%. Kot et al. employed pure silica-based SBA-3 molecular sieves and Al-doped Al-SBA-3 as supports for nickel (Ni) loading [30]. The addition of Al to the carrier introduced Lewis acidic sites, improving the adsorption and activation of toluene and enhancing toluene hydrogenation activity. Additionally, Al-SBA-3 demonstrated superior structural characteristics and appropriate metal-support interactions, resulting in the formation of less dispersed nickel particles. In recent studies on LOHCs, noble metal catalysts such as ruthenium and rhodium have been extensively utilized in the hydrogenation process. However, their high cost limits their large-scale implementation. On the other hand, non-precious metal catalysts, which are more affordable, have received less attention. Both nickel (Ni) and ruthenium (Ru) have attracted researchers' interest due to their similar catalytic properties in hydrogen storage materials. Since cobalt (Co) and nickel (Ni) are both transition metals and belong to the same periodic group, they are theoretically expected to exhibit comparable catalytic activities in LOHCs. However, research on cobalt-based catalysts for LOHC applications remains limited. To fill in the gap and improve the catalytic hydrogenation activity of LOHCs, in this study, a series of high Co loaded composite carriers were prepared using a one-step co-precipitation method. The as-prepared Co catalysts with various measured ratios were designated as Co/AlxSi1O for simplicity. The hydrogenation of NPCZ was systematically examined, with a focus on the role of Co-based catalyst carriers. Hydrogenation experiments of NPCZ were conducted in the presence of catalysts with different Al/Si ratios to determine the optimal carrier components. Comprehensive characterization of these catalysts was performed using a series of characterizations to elucidate their physicochemical properties. Furthermore, in order to understand the enhancement of catalytic activity, we employed DFT calculations to elucidate the relationship between the Al/Si content on the modulation of electronic structure and performance of the catalysts. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials Na2SiO3·9H2O (AR), Na2CO3 (AR), Al(NO3)3·9H2O (AR), and PEG 2000 (AR), were procured from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd., Shanghai, China. A blend of argon and hydrogen gas (comprising 10 vol% H2) and ultra-pure hydrogen (with a purity of 99.999 %). All chemicals were used for the synthesis of the catalysts without further purification. 2.2 Preparation of catalysts A confluence of 17.28 g of Co(NO3)2·6H2O and 8.53 g of Al(NO3)3·9H2O were dissolved in 100 mL of deionized water to obtain Solution A. Subsequently, 1.61 g of Na2SiO3·9H2O and 11.29 g of Na2CO3 were dissolved in 100 mL of deionized water to yield Solution B. Additionally, 0.5 g of PEG 2000 was dissolved in 200 mL of deionized water to produce Solution C. Solution A and solution B were gradually introduced into solution C at a temperature of 90 °C, while maintaining continuous stirring until a green precipitate formed. Subsequently, the precipitate was allowed to cool naturally to room temperature, the precipitate was filtered out and washed using deionized water until the wash solution was neutral. Subsequently, the precipitate was uniformly distributed in 200 mL of anhydrous ethanol and exposed to an oil bath at 120 °C to completely remove the ethanol and form the catalyst precursor. The precursor was ground into powder and roasted in a muffle furnace at 600 °C for 1 h. Finally, the powder was sieved through a 50-mesh sieve and placed in a tubular furnace. The catalyst was reduced with an Ar/H2 (10 % H2) mixture at 700 °C for 6 h, followed by passivation with 1 % O2/Ar at room temperature for 1 h, yielding a Co70/Al4Si1O catalyst with a Co loading of 70 wt% and an Al/Si molar ratio of 4/1. The above method was used to adjust the amounts of Al(NO3)3·9H2O and Na2SiO3·9H2O, resulting in the synthesis of Co-based catalysts with different Al/Si molar ratios, labeled as Co70/Al2O3, Co70/Al6Si1O, Co70/Al4Si1O, Co70/Al2Si1O, Co70/Al1Si1O, and Co70/SiO2 catalysts. Table S1 details the amount of major raw materials used in the catalyst preparation process. 2.3 Catalyst characterization The X-ray diffraction analysis was conducted using a D8 Focus X-ray diffractometer manufactured by Bruker AXS, Germany. The instrument employed Cu-Kα radiation (λ = 1.54 Å) as the X-ray source, with a scanning speed of 10°/min and a scanning angle range of 10-90°. The operational conditions for the instrument were set at 40 kV and 30 mA. The N2 adsorption–desorption data were obtained using an ASAP-2460 physical adsorption instrument. The preconditioning of the samples involved vacuum degassing at 200 °C for a duration of 6 h. The specific surface area of the samples was calculated using the Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) equation, while the pore volume and pore diameter data were ascertained through the Barrett-Joyner-Halenda (BJH) equation. The elemental content of Al and Si in the catalyst was determined using an Optima 5300 DV Inductively Coupled Plasma Optical Emission Spectrometer (ICP-OES) manufactured by PerkinElmer. H2 temperature programmed reduction (H2-TPR) and NH3 temperature programmed desorption (NH3-TPD) analyses were conducted on a Micromeritics AutoChem 2950 HP instrument to evaluate the redox properties and surface acidity of the catalyst, respectively. H2 temperature programmed desorption (H2-TPD) and H2 chemisorption was performed on a BSD-Chem C200 instrument to further characterize the catalysts (see Supporting Information ). In situ FTIR analysis of carbon monoxide (CO-DRIFT) was conducted on a Thermo Fisher Nicolet iS50 to investigate the chemical properties of active sites on the surface of catalysts. Detailed descriptions of the testing and data processing is provided in the Supporting Information . X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) analyses were conducted using an ESCALAB 250Xi instrument from Thermo Fisher Scientific. The excitation source employed was Al-Kα radiation. All data were charge-corrected using the C 1s binding energy (284.80 eV) as the energy standard. High-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM) images were acquired using a JEOL-JEM-2100F instrument from Japan to analyze the overall morphology, structure, and dispersion of the catalyst. 2.4 Catalytic performance evaluation Evaluating the catalyst performance by measuring the hydrogenation reaction rate of N-propylcarbazole (NPCZ). A total of 2 g of NPCZ and 0.2 g of catalyst were added to a 250 mL high-pressure reaction vessel (Shanghai LABE instrument LB250), along with 40 mL of n-hexane. The reaction vessel was connected to the main apparatus and purged three times with pure hydrogen to thoroughly eliminate air from the system. After initiating and stabilizing the cooling system, the temperature was gradually raised to 150 °C. Once the temperature stabilized, 7 MPa of hydrogen gas was injected into the system and the stirring rate was set to 600 r/min. Samples were regularly extracted throughout the entire reaction process and analyzed using GC-MS (Agilent 7890/5975C) to closely track the hydrogenation process. 2.5 Computational methods The theoretical calculations were based on density functional theory (DFT) and performed using the Vienna Ab-initio Simulation Package (VASP). The calculations incorporated electronic spin polarization and utilized the Perdew Burke Ernzerhof (PBE) generalized gradient approximation (GGA) to describe the electron exchange correlation energy. The plane-wave calculations employed the projector-augmented wave (PAW) method with a plane-wave basis set energy cutoff of 400 eV. To account for computational efficiency and accurate Brillouin zone integration, the k-point grid for Monkhorst-Pack sampling was set to (1 × 1 × 1). Additionally, electronic self-consistency was achieved with a convergence threshold of 10-5 eV, and force convergence was set at 0.03 eV/Å to ensure sufficient accuracy in the calculations. Utilizing sub-nanometric clusters for analyzing nanocatalysts' chemical reactivity is a widely accepted method [31]. Many studies on support modification effects on catalytic activity, typically uses smaller metal clusters with cleaved support surface models [32–34]. Theoretical calculations of this work were introduced primarily to show the Al/Si content's effect on the Co metal's electron density via the d-band center and Bader charge. This is to clarify the metal-carrier interaction's role in catalyst improvement and its variance in hydrogenation reaction energetics. Consequently, we created a model combining Co10 clusters with 6 cleaved Al-Si-O support surfaces. The analysis of the catalyst's structure indicated that the γ-Al2O3 bulk could be constructed based on Digne's γ-Al2O3 structural model [35]. This optimized γ-Al2O3 bulk was sliced along the (001) plane using Materials Studio (MS) software, and the lattice vector was redefined after doubling the cell extension along the U-direction, resulting in an Al2O3(001) surface with a lattice parameter of 13.93 × 13.93. To prevent interactions of periodic atoms in the c-direction, a vacuum layer of 20 Å was added, resulting in a Al2O3(001) superlattice structure (13.93 × 13.93 × 26.42) containing 64 Al atoms and 96 O atoms. The pristine Al atoms were substituted by Si atoms based on Si/Al molar ratios of 0, 1:6, 1:4, 1:2, and 1:1, with corresponding doping numbers of Si atoms being 0, 9, 13, 21, and 32, labeled as Al2O3, Al6Si1O, Al4Si1O, Al2Si1O, and Al1Si1O, respectively. It is worthwhile to note that there are numerous doping sites for Si. We randomly generated nine structures for each model mainly by vaspkit software to screen out the most stable structure with adsorbed Co10 clusters. Additionally, SiO2 was sliced along (111) and expanded into a 3 × 3 × 1 cell, and a 15.70 × 15.70 × 31.21 slab model of SiO2(111) was obtained by adding 20 Å vacuum layers. Co clusters were loaded onto the surface of SiO2(111), leading to the formation of a SiO2(111) structure containing 54Si atoms, 108O atoms, and 10 Co atoms, namely Co10/SiO2. The investigation into the electronic structures and catalytic NPCZ hydrogenation process of Co10/Al2O3, Co10/Al6Si1O, Co10/Al4Si1O, Co10/Al2Si1O, Co10/Al1Si1O, and Co10/SiO2 offered insights into the impact of the composite carriers on the structure and performance of the catalysts. Among them, the top and side views of the Co10/Al2O3, Co10/Al6Si1O, Co10/Al4Si1O, Co10/Al2Si1O, Co10/Al1Si1O, and Co10/SiO2 models are shown in Fig. S2-6 . The adsorption energy (ΔEads) is calculated as per Equation (1), where Em/slab represents the total electronic energy of the catalyst-adsorbate system, Eslab is the total electronic energy of the catalyst. Em is the total electronic energy of the adsorbate molecule. The reaction energy (ΔH) for the transformation of reactants (R) to products (P) on the catalyst surface is calculated as per Equation (2). (1) Δ E ads = E slab + i - E slab - E i (2) Δ H = E P - E R 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Structural characterization of the catalyst The X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns presented in Fig. 1 (a) provide information about the phase compositions of catalysts with different Al/Si ratios. In the Co70/SiO2 catalyst, the diffraction peaks observed at 44.2°, 51.5°, and 75.8° correspond to the face-centered cubic structure of cobalt (PDF#15–0806). Additionally, diffraction peaks at 41.6° and 47.4° are associated with the hexagonal close-packed structure of cobalt (PDF#89-4308) [36,37]. The intensity of the 44.2° diffraction peak decreases notably with the increase of aluminum content in the catalyst, indicating a reduction in the particle size of cobalt nanoparticles. The diffraction peaks associated with the hexagonal close-packed structure of cobalt completely disappeared in the Co70/Al2Si1O catalyst. This finding suggests that the introduction of Al2O3 into Co70/SiO2 can significantly improve the dispersion properties of cobalt nanoparticles and have a profound effect on the crystal structure of metallic cobalt nanoparticles. Table 1 presents the particle size of cobalt nanoparticles in catalysts with different aluminum contents calculated using Scherrer's formula. Notably, the Co70/Al4Si1O catalyst features the smallest size of metallic cobalt nanoparticles. It is significant that Co70/Al2O3 exhibits more characteristic diffraction peaks compared to Co70/SiO2. The peaks observed at 31.3°, 36.8°, 59.3°, and 65.3° correspond to characteristic peaks of CoAl2O4 or Co3O4, as referenced in PDF#44-0160 and PDF#43-1003, respectively. This indicates that the cobalt species in Co70/Al2O3 are mainly in an oxidized state or part of a spinel structure, suggesting a stronger interaction between Al2O3 and Co than between SiO2 and Co [29]. In addition, the characteristic diffraction peaks of Al2O3 and SiO2 were not observed in any of the catalyst samples, suggesting that these two oxides are present in the catalyst in a highly dispersed amorphous form. Fig. 1 (b) illustrates the N2 isothermal adsorption and desorption curves of the Co70/AlxSi1O catalysts, while Table 1 summarizes the specific surface area, pore volume, and pore size data of the catalysts. In Fig. 1 (b), all catalysts exhibit a classical type IV curve with a distinct hysteresis loop in the relative pressure range of 0.8–1.0, indicating that the catalysts possess a mesoporous structure [38]. Specifically, the hysteresis loop of Co70/Al2O3 catalyst exhibits an H4 type, whereas the rest of the catalysts show H3 type hysteresis loops. The isotherms of the Co70/AlxSi1O catalysts do not show a clear saturated adsorption plateau in the high-pressure region, which implies that the catalysts possess an irregular slit-pore structure. The data in Table 1 indicates that the specific surface area and pore volume of Co70/Al2O3 catalyst are 41 m2/g and 0.16 cm3/g, respectively, attributed to its component CoAl2O4 being a macroporous or nonporous material. The specific surface area of the composite support ranges from 86 to 126 m2/g, clearly demonstrating that the addition of Si element can significantly increase the specific surface area of the catalyst and promote the dispersion of Co meta l[39]. Furthermore, the pore volume and pore size of Co70/Al4Si1O, Co70/Al2Si1O, and Co70/Al1Si1O catalysts have been significantly enhanced, which will help to reduce the transfer and diffusion resistance of reactants, thus improving the catalytic hydrogenation activity. The catalyst reduction capacity and the metal-support interaction were analyzed using H2 temperature programmed reduction (H2-TPR) technique, and the corresponding results are shown in Fig. 1 (c). The hydrogen desorption peak of Co70/Al2O3 shows a significant increase in 200–500 °C, indicating the presence of a large number of cobalt oxide species in Co70/Al2O3, consistent with XRD results. The hydrogen depletion peak observed at 148 °C in the low temperature range of Co70/SiO2 is attributed to the reduction of surface cobalt oxide species that have interacted with the carriers, potentially formed during the passivation treatment. After the addition of Al2O3 to the catalyst, the reduction peaks in the low-temperature range were obviously shifted to high temperatures, and the areas of these peaks gradually decreased with the increase of Al2O3 content. Meanwhile, the reduction peak of Co70/AlxSi1O appeared in high temperature (250–300 °C) region, which was attributed to the strong interaction of the cobalt oxide species with the AlxSi1O carrier. The intensity of the reduction peak of Co70/Al4Si1O in the high-temperature region increased with the increase of Al2O3 content, suggesting that the addition of Al2O3 aids in modulating the strength of the interaction between cobalt nanoparticles and carriers. Particularly, the cobalt-carrier interaction in Co70/Al4Si1O is most evident when the Al/Si ratio is adjusted to 4, highlighting the significant role of Al2O3 content in optimizing this interaction. The effective Co species area exposed in catalysts with different Al/Si ratios was measured by H2 chemisorption, with specific measurement and calculation methods detailed in the supporting information. The surface area of Co and the particle size of Co nanoparticles calculated based on H2 chemisorption are listed in Table 1 [40]. It is noteworthy that the size of Co nanoparticles obtained from chemisorption data is significantly higher than that calculated by XRD, indicating that not all Co species can stably adsorb and dissociate hydrogen. Further calculations were conducted to determine the exposed effective area of Co species in different catalysts. As the content of Al2O3 increases, the surface area of the effective Co species exposed by the catalysts exhibits a volcano-shaped variation, with the maximum surface area of active Co species in Co70/Al4Si1O reaching 9.82 m2/g. This also suggests that Co70/Al4Si1O has more hydrogen dissociation active sites [41,42]. The NH3 temperature programmed desorption (NH3-TPD) analysis provides insights into the distribution of acidic sites and surface density of the acidic site for catalysts, therefore, NH3-TPD curves of all the as-synthesized catalysts are illustrated in Fig. 1 (d). Specifically, the ammonia desorption peaks centered at 50–120 °C, 120–220 °C, 220–300 °C, and 300–500 °C can be respectively attributed to the effects of weak acidic sites, intermediate acidic sites, strong acidic sites, and very-strong acidic sites. Table 2 details the total acidity of the catalysts and surface density of the acidic site. The comparative analysis indicates that the introduction of Al2O3 into the silica support leads to an initial increase followed by a decrease in the overall acidity of the catalyst. Further investigation into the distribution of different acid strength sites reveals a clear correlation between silica content and the presence of weak acid sites, while Al2O3 primarily affects the strong acid sites of the catalyst. With increasing aluminum content, the number of weak acid sites shows a decreasing trend, while the number of very-strong acid sites significantly increases. It is worth noting that when Al2O3 is used as the only support, the catalyst exhibits strong and very-strong acidity compared to other catalysts. Excessive acidity is detrimental to the desorption of reactants and may lead to carbon deposition or coverage of the acidic sites of the catalysts, thus negatively affecting the hydrogenation reaction [43,44]. As summarized and detailly compared in Table 2, the Co70/Al4Si1O catalyst possesses a better specific surface area and Al content, resulting in a uniform surface density distribution of various types of acidic sites, indicative of promoting the catalytic hydrogenation reaction. In order to study the valence state of Co species and the interaction between Co and carriers in the catalysts, the Al 2p, O 1s and Co 2p orbitals in the relevant catalysts were analyzed by XPS. The XPS spectra of Al 2p in the catalysts are shown in Fig. 2 (a), and the main peak located near 74 eV corresponds to the Al3+ species. With the Al content decreases, the peaks of the Al3+ species are slightly shifted toward higher binding energies, indicating an increase in the ionicity of the Al-O bond or a decrease in the density of the Al2O3 phase, which is consistent with the results of the Al/Si ratios detected by ICP-OES in Table 1 [45]. The O 1s XPS spectrum in Fig. 2 (b) is decomposed into three peaks, which are correspondingly attributed to lattice oxygen, O and OH in the catalysts [46,47]. Compared with Co70/Al2O3, the lattice oxygen contents in Co70/Al6Si1O, Co70/Al4Si1O, Co70/Al2Si1O, and Co70/Al1Si1O catalysts showed a tendency of declining at the beginning followed by increasing ( Table S2 ), which indicated that more oxygen vacancies were formed in Co70/Al4Si1O catalysts. However, the metal-bound O species (M−O) demonstrated an increasing trend, indicating that the increase of silica content weakened the metal-carrier interaction and led to the increase of oxidized Co species in the catalysts. Notably, the large amount of –OH functional groups on the surface of silica carriers resulted in a high content of M−OH species of 36.09 % ( Table S2 ). Fig. 2 (c) profiles the fitting peaks of catalyst Co 2p3/2 orbitals, with the peak at 777.83 ± 0.4 eV corresponding to the Co0 species, and a convolution peak at a binding energy of 780.36 ± 0.4 eV indicating the presence of the Co3O4 species [38,48]. It can be visualized that the characteristic peaks of Co0 species are shifted to the range of lower binding energies. This phenomenon suggests that the acidity of the catalyst is weakened as the SiO2 content increases, and the bonding interactions between the metal and Al2O3 also undermined, thus making the Co2+ and Co3+ species more easily to be reduced to metallic Co (Co0). This finding is in line with the reduction peaks shift to the low temperature region in the H2-TPR plots (Fig. 1 c). In Table S3 , the Co0 content in Co70/SiO2 catalyst is only 8.19 %, indicating that the passivation process leads to the oxidation of the surface metal due to the weak interaction of the metal carriers. While the Co0 content in Co70/Al4Si1O catalyst can be as high as 19.03 %, which suggests that the appropriate Al/Si ratio promotes the reduction of Co species, consistent with above-analyzed XRD and H2-TPR results. We further explored the impact of the Al/Si ratio on the geometry and electronic structure of Co nanoparticles within the catalysts, employing H2 and CO as molecular probes. The findings from H2-TPD and CO-DRIFT spectroscopy are illustrated in Fig. 3 . As shown in Fig. 3 (a), the detachment peaks are associated with weakly adsorbed hydrogen species in the low-temperature region below 100 °C, whereas the detachment peaks are associated with strongly adsorbed hydrogen species in the high-temperature region from 150 to 200 °C. It is well known that weakly adsorbed hydrogen species usually bind to metal nanoparticles, whereas strongly adsorbed hydrogen species tend to attach to positively charged nanoparticles. The synergistic interaction between the metal and positively charged nanoparticles is essential for promoting hydrogen heterocleavage and stabilizing the hydrogen species, thus enhancing the hydrogenation activity of the catalyst, as confirmed by the study of Zhao et al [34]. Doping of Al2O3 into the catalyst resulted in a pronounced desorption peak in the high temperature range, indicating the presence of positively charged Coδ+ nanoparticles. The intensity of the desorption peak in the low-temperature region gradually decreased with increasing Al2O3 content, while the intensity of the desorption peak in the high-temperature region increased accordingly. This observation is consistent with the TPR characterization, indicating that the interaction between Co nanoparticles and carriers is enhanced due to the presence of Al2O3. In addition, XPS characterization further reveals that the addition of Al2O3 to Co70/SiO2 leads to the loss of electrons in the metallic Co nanoparticles, thus changing their electronic structure. Fig. 3 (b) demonstrates the results of CO-DRIFT spectra of Co70/AlxSi1O, obtained by subtracting the background spectrum from the absorption spectrum after the sample adsorbed CO sufficiently. Vibrational peaks at 2025 cm−1, 1950 cm−1, and 1860 cm−1 observed in Co70/SiO2 are attributed to three different adsorption states of CO: linear adsorption, bridged adsorption, and geminal (or paired) adsorption. The appearance of geminal adsorption is significantly influenced by the size of the metal nanoparticles, with larger nanoparticles more likely to form this adsorption mode. The introduction of Al2O3 leads to a higher wavenumber shift of the vibrational peak at 1860 cm−1 and a significant decrease in peak intensity, indicating a reduction in the size of Co nanoparticles inside the catalyst, consistent with XRD characterization results. With increasing Al2O3 content, the peaks corresponding to linear adsorption and bridge adsorption of CO shift to higher wavenumbers, suggesting a weakening of the interaction between Co nanoparticles and the bonds in CO, as well as a decrease in the adsorption strength of CO. It is generally recognized that there exists a volcano-shaped relationship between catalyst activity and the strength of reactant adsorption. The optimal reactant adsorption strength is critical for both the full activation of reactant molecules and the efficient release of products. The collective results from XPS, H2-TPD, and CO-DRIFT analyses indicate that the incorporation of Al2O3 into Co70/SiO2 modifies the electronic structure of Co nanoparticles. This alteration impacts their adsorption and stabilization of hydrogen species and adjusts the strength of their interactions with unsaturated π-bonds, thus affecting the overall performance of the catalyst. The morphology and particle size of the as-prepared catalysts were observed through the TEM images. As presented in Fig. 4 (a), the Co70/Al4Si1O catalyst is consisted of irregular sheet-like structure, and it can be clearly observed that numerous black Co nanoparticles are uniformly located on the surface. The high-resolution TEM (HRTEM) image shows lattice fringes corresponding to the Co3O4 (400), Co (200), and Co (111), demonstrating the co-existence of metallic Co and oxidized Co (Fig. 4 (b)). Additionally, from selected area electron diffraction (SAED) image (Fig. 4 (c)), the formation of polycrystalline structures is observed again. Furthermore, the HAADF-STEM image and the corresponding EDX elemental mapping images confirm that the sample is composed of Co, O, Al, and Si elements, indicating the successful preparation of Co70/Al4Si1O catalyst (Fig. 4 (d)). Besides that, as profiled in Fig. S1(a), the Co70/SiO2 catalyst displays a blocky sheet-like structure. Conversely, with an increased Al content, the catalyst progressively exhibits a wrinkled sheet-like structure (Fig. S1(b)-(f)). Unsurprisingly, the nanoparticle size in the Co70/SiO2 catalyst is significantly larger than that of other catalysts. However, after the introduction of Al element, the nanoparticle size in Co70/Al2Si1O and Co70/Al1Si1O catalysts is slightly reduced as expected. Judging by the nanoparticle distribution situation, among all the catalysts, the Co70/Al6Si1O and Co70/Al4Si1O catalysts demonstrate apparently excellent nanoparticle dispersion phenomenon. According to statistical analysis, the average nanoparticle size of Co70/Al2O3, Co70/Al6Si1O, Co70/Al4Si1O, Co70/Al2Si1O, Co70/Al1Si1O, and Co70/SiO2 catalysts is 13.5 nm, 13.3 nm, 12.7 nm, 14.5 nm, 19.5 nm, and 24.6 nm, respectively, with these values are very close to the results analyzed from XRD patterns (Table 1) It is noteworthy that although the specific surface area of the Co70/Al2O3 catalyst is only 41 m2/g, the size of the metal particles is smaller compared to the catalysts using pure SiO2 carriers or Al/Si ratios ≤ 2. This phenomenon can be attributed to several factors. First, the presence of the CoAl2O4 phase in the Co70/Al2O3 catalyst reduces the specific surface area of the catalyst. Second, the strong interaction between aluminum and carriers contributes to a more homogeneous dispersion of the active species on the catalyst surface. This enhanced dispersion favors the formation of smaller metal particles. Despite showing no significant agglomeration phenomenon, the nanoparticle size in the Co70/SiO2 catalyst (Fig. S1(a)) is larger than the Co70/AlxSi1O catalyst, reaching up to 24.6 nm, which is attributing to the weak interaction between the metallic species and the unmodified SiO2 carrier. However, as observed in Fig. S1 (c), the Co70/Al4Si1O catalyst as expected showcases an optimal nanoparticle size by virtue of its suitable specific surface area and balanced distribution of acidic sites, as manifested above. 3.2 Evaluation of catalytic activity The catalytic activity of the as-prepared catalysts was assessed for the hydrogenation of NPCZ, which has a theoretical hydrogen storage capacity of 5.43 wt%. This hydrogenation process involves three steps: the initial transformation of NPCZ to tetrahydro-N-propylcarbazole (4H-NPCZ), its subsequent hydrogenation to octahydro-N-propylcarbazole (8H-NPCZ), and the final conversion of 8H-NPCZ to perhydro-N-propylcarbazole (12H-NPCZ) [34]. The product distribution as function of reaction time during the hydrogenation process of all catalysts is summarized in Fig. 5 . In terms of the Co70/SiO2 catalyst, as demonstrated in Fig. 5 (f), it is obvious that its catalytic performance of NPCZ hydrogenation is highly unsatisfactory, as only 26.6 % of NPCZ was converted when the hydrogenation reaction was carried out for 240 min, and the 12H-NPCZ was barely detectable. This poor performance of the Co70/SiO2 catalyst was mainly attributed to the weak metal-carrier interactions, rendering its larger Co metal nanoparticles (24.6 nm in Fig. S1 f) showing negative impact on its hydrogenation activity. In addition, the low density of acidic sites on the surface of the Co70/SiO2 catalyst prevented it from effectively adsorbing the NPCZ, and therefore unable to trigger the deep hydrogenation reaction. As anticipated, The Co70/Al2O3 catalyst with more strong acidic sites can effectively induce the conversion of NPCZ to 4H-NPCZ (Fig. 5 (a)). However, the enhanced alkalinity of the intermediates makes it difficult to be detached from the catalyst surface, which leads to the catalytic hydrogenation process mainly staying in the conversion stages of 4H-NPCZ to 8H-NPCZ and 8H-NPCZ to 12H-NPCZ conversions. The product distribution of Co70/Al6Si1O, Co70/Al4Si1O and Co70/Al2Si1O catalysts is similar (Fig. 5 (b)-5(d)), while the time to achieve a complete conversion of NPCZ is of high difference that requires 90 min, 20 min and 120 min, respectively. Despite both the Co70/Al6Si1O and Co70/Al2Si1O catalysts show accumulation of 4H-NPCZ and 8H-NPCZ intermediates (∼40 %) during hydrogenation, the Co70/Al4Si1O catalyst discloses a higher accumulation of 8H-NPCZ than that of 4H-NPCZ (Fig. 5 (c)). In comparison, the Co70/Al6Si1O (Fig. 5 (b)) and Co70/Al2Si1O (Fig. 5 (d)) catalysts are less active, as they need about 2.78 times longer to complete the NPCZ hydrogenation than that of the Co70/Al4Si1O catalyst (Fig. 5 (c)). Consequently, the Co70/Al4Si1O catalyst exhibits the most optimal catalytic activity for NPCZ hydrogenation, consistent with the conclusions drew from the physiochemical property analyses. To straightforwardly distinguish the discrepancies in hydrogen storage capability and a clearer hydrogenation activity comparison, the NPCZ hydrogenation results of all the catalysts are outlined in Fig. 6 (a). Specifically, the hydrogenation activity follows the order of Co70/Al4Si1O > Co70/Al6Si1O ≈ Co70/Al2Si1O ＞Co70/Al2O3 ≈ Co70/Al1Si1O ＞ Co70/SiO2. The ultralow catalytic hydrogen storage capability of the Co70/Al1Si1O and Co70/SiO2 catalysts are a result of their low contents of surface acids, consequently, displaying inferior adsorption capability toward NPCZ and the subsequent inefficient hydrogenation behavior. On top of that, the inertness of the carriers leads to the aggregation of nanoparticles, hence, unfavorable for a higher catalytic hydrogenation activity. As to the Co70/Al2O3 catalyst, the compromised hydrogenation activity is due to the lack of enough active sites, and additional excessive acid content further leads to the desorption of intermediate products. The stability of catalysts is a key factor for its practical application in industrial processes. To assess the stability of the Co70/Al4Si1O catalyst, we conducted 10 cycles of NPCZ hydrogenation under the conditions of 150 °C and 7 MPa hydrogen pressure. Following each hydrogenation cycle, the catalysts were reused without any additional treatment for subsequent experiments. The hydrogen uptake versus time curves from these ten hydrogenation cycles are depicted in Fig. 6 (b). These curves demonstrate that the Co70/Al4Si1O catalyst is capable of maintaining robust catalytic performance across all 10 cycles, with the 10th cycle successfully achieving complete hydrogenation of NPCZ within 180 min. A slight decrease in catalytic activity is observed compared to the initial cycle, which may be attributed to minor catalyst loss and cobalt oxidation resulting from exposure to air, leading to a slight impact on the efficiency of the catalyst. To elucidate the kinetics of NPCZ hydrogenation catalyzed by Co70/Al4Si1O catalysts, the concentration versus time data from the NPCZ hydrogenation reaction were analyzed using a first-order kinetic model (see Supporting Information ). The resulting plots, which illustrate the variation of ln(CNPCZ/C0) against reaction time t at four different temperatures, are presented in Fig. 6 (c). In these plots, the reaction rate constant k is determined by the slope of the fitted curves. The apparent activation energy (Ea) can be derived from the slope (-Ea/R) of the plot of lnk against 1/T, as shown in Fig. 6 (d). From this analysis, the apparent activation energy for the catalytic hydrogenation of NPCZ by Co70/Al4Si1O catalyst was found to be 64.53 kJ/mol. This value is lower than the reported apparent activation energy for ruthenium-based catalysts, which stands at 70.09 kJ/mol [49]. Table 3 lists the catalytic NPCZ hydrogenation activity observed in this study and some of the hydrogenation catalysts reported in previous studies. Notably, the Co70/Al4Si1O catalyst synthesized in this study exhibits the most superior performance, achieving the complete hydrogenation of NPCZ in just 90 min with only half catalyst usage amount compared to the reported high-performance Ru0.5-WO3 catalyst (Table 3). Based on the comprehensive materials characterization results, this outstanding catalytic hydrogenation performance of the Co70/Al4Si1O catalyst is attributed to its excellent mesopore structure, to reduce the diffusion resistance of reactants, and the balanced acidic sites that enhance the interaction with metal carriers for a high dispersion of nanoparticles, thus ushering a significantly enhanced catalytic NPCZ hydrogenation activity. 3.3 DFT calculations To further analyze the effect of Al/Si ratio on metal-carrier interactions, we analyzed the density of states, d-band centers, and Bader charges of the Co10/Al2O3, Co10/Al6Si1O, Co10/Al4Si1O, Co10/Al2Si1O, Co10/Al1Si1O, and Co10/SiO2 models in order to explore the relationship between the structure of the catalysts and the hydrogenation activity. Fig. 7 shows the density of states projected on the d orbitals of Co10 clusters in each surface model. The d-band center values of Co10 clusters in Co10/Al2O3, Co10/Al6Si1O, Co10/Al4Si1O, Co10/Al2Si1O, Co10/Al1Si1O, and Co10/SiO2 were calculated to be −2.44, −2.32, −2.11, −2.15, −2.31, and −2.46 eV, respectively. It is particularly worth mentioning that the d-band center of Co in the Co10/Al4Si1O is closer to the Fermi energy level than other structural models, a property that gives it excellent catalytic performance, which coincides with the results of our prominence catalytic performance tests of Co70/Al4Si1O catalyst. The Bader charges of Co10 clusters in the structural models of Co10/Al2O3, Co10/Al6Si1O, Co10/Al4Si1O, Co10/Al2Si1O, Co10/Al1Si1O, and Co10/SiO2 were deeply analyzed (Table S4). Analysis shows that the total Bader charge of Co on the surface of Co10/Al2O3 is 89.03, indicating that Co is in an electron-deficient state. This is mainly due to the strong acidity of Al2O3, which leads to excessive interaction between Co and the carrier, causing the surface Co of the catalyst to lose electrons. With the increase of Si content, the acidity of the catalyst gradually weakens, and XPS results show that the binding energy of Co0 gradually shifts towards the lower direction, indicating that Co gains electrons. This results in the gradual increase of the total Bader charge of Co on the surface of the catalyst, reaching a maximum of 90.57 on the surface of Co10/Al4Si1O. However, when the Si content is too high, the ability to gain electrons decreases due to the weaker interaction between Co and the carrier, resulting in a decrease in the total Bader charge of Co on the surface of Co10/SiO2 to 90.07. This series of results indicates that by adjusting the Al/Si molar ratio in the catalyst, the electron environment on the surface of Co can be effectively controlled, thereby affecting the catalytic performance of the catalyst. The adsorption energies of NPCZ and its intermediates on the surface of various catalysts were further studied through discussion of density of states and Bader charge ( Table S4 ). As shown in Fig. 8 , 0 eV is a relative measure for the energy level at which NPCZ is stably adsorbed on the catalyst surface. The absolute energy values for the six structures are as follows: −1425.92 eV (Co10/Al2O3), −1424.56 eV (Co10/Al6Si1O), −1423.58 eV (Co10/Al4Si1O), −1420.19 eV (Co10/Al2Si1O), −1419.05 eV (Co10/Al1Si1O), and −1486.62 eV (Co10/SiO2), respectively. The reaction energies in the NPCZ → 4H-NPCZ, 4H-NPCZ → 8H-NPCZ, and 8H-NPCZ → 12H-NPCZ hydrogenation reactions were labeled as ΔH1, ΔH2, and ΔH3, as illustrated in Fig. 8. Since NPCZ hydrogenation is an exothermic reaction, the greater the absolute value of the reaction energy, the easier the hydrogenation reaction can proceed. The reaction energies of Co10/Al2O3, Co10/Al6Si1O, Co10/Al4Si1O, Co10/Al2Si1O, Co10/Al1Si1O, and Co10/SiO2 for the conversion of NPCZ → 4H-NPCZ were −1.05, −1.26, −1.30, −1.14, −1.23, and −0.97 eV, while the corresponding adsorption energies for NPCZ were −2.55, −2.18, −2.07, −1.86, −1.89, and −1.25 eV, respectively. Combined with the results of the NH3-TPD, it can be seen that the Al2O3 carriers with strong acidity showed excessive adsorption of NPCZ capacity, limiting its transformation to the next product. Conversely, the SiO2 carrier has weakened acidity and cannot form effective adsorption on NPCZ, which is unfavorable to the hydrogenation reaction. With the increase of Si content, the reaction energies of each catalyst for the conversion of 8H-NPCZ → 12H-NPCZ were −0.36, −0.59, −0.97, −0.90, −0.82, and −0.80 eV, respectively. When the intermediate products of 4H-NPCZ and 8H-NPCZ were generated, the adsorbate formed a d-π feedback interaction with the Co10 cluster. At this point, the reaction difficulty is related to the density of the electron cloud around the Co10 cluster. Combined with Bader's charge analysis, it is observed that excessive Al content leads to an electron-deficient state in Co10 clusters. Conversely, excessive Si content leads to weak interaction between Co and the carrier, resulting in lower electron cloud density around Co10 clusters. In Co10/Al4Si1O catalysts, Co10 clusters and adsorbates can form a strong d-π feedback interaction, promoting the conversion of 8H-NPCZ to 12H-NPCZ. These conclusions demonstrate that the Al/Si ratio in the catalyst significantly affects the acid-base and electronic structure of the catalyst, which in turn affects the catalytic hydrogenation activity of the catalyst. 4 Conclusion In this study, the hydrogenation of NPCZ was investigated using cobalt-based catalysts synthesized with Al2O3-SiO2 carriers. The utilization of composite carriers demonstrated several advantages over single-component catalysts, including enhanced specific surface area, robust metal-support interactions, and an ideal distribution of acidic sites. Adjusting the Al/Si ratio significantly alters the Co nanoparticles' electronic structure, impacting hydrogen species adsorption and interaction with NPCZ intermediates, as evidenced by XPS, H2-TPD, and CO-DRIFT analyses. Notably, the addition of aluminum strengthened the metal-support interaction and promoted improved dispersion of cobalt, resulting in a reduction in cobalt particle size. However, it is important to note that excessive aluminum content can have detrimental effects on the catalyst, such as reducing the specific surface area and pore structure, as well as creating an abundance of acidic sites that may hinder the optimization of catalytic function. Among the catalysts studied, the Co70/Al4Si1O catalysts with an Al/Si ratio of 4:1 exhibited optimal catalytic activity and reducibility. Among the catalysts studied, the Co70/Al4Si1O catalyst with an Al/Si ratio of 4:1 showed the best catalytic activity and reducibility, with an activation energy for hydrogenation of 64.53 kJ/mol. Remarkably, the Co70/Al4Si1O catalyst maintained robust catalytic performance across 10 cycles, with the 10th cycle achieving complete hydrogenation of NPCZ within 180 min. DFT analysis showed that the increased density of the electron cloud of Co10 clusters in Co10/Al4Si1O was conducive to the formation of a d-π feedback interaction between the catalyst and the adsorbent, promoting the catalytic hydrogenation reaction. Furthermore, the adsorption energy of the composite carrier surpassed that of the single-component carrier, aligning with the higher catalytic efficiency observed experimentally. Overall, this work provides valuable guidance for future refinements and advancements in the design of cobalt-based catalysts. coredata.dc:description: We developed a series of high-loading Co-Al2O3-SiO2 catalysts to enhance the hydrogenation of N-propylcarbazole (NPCZ) by fine-tuning the Al/Si ratio. Our research reveals that adjusting this ratio can significantly modify the electronic structure of Co nanoparticles, as confirmed by XPS, H2-TPD, and CO-DRIFT analyses, thereby affecting the adsorption of hydrogen species and their interaction with unsaturated π-bonds of NPCZ intermediates. Optimal Al concentration promotes Co nanoparticles dispersion, while excessive Al leads to increased acidity and reduced surface area. The Co70/Al4Si1O catalyst, with an Al/Si ratio of 4, demonstrated superior hydrogenation efficiency by enabling fast and stable hydrogenation of NPCZ, achieving an activation energy of 64.53 kJ/mol and maintaining high performance over 10 cycles. Through DFT calculations, we explored the d-band center and Bader charge across 6 different Co10/Al-Si-O models and assessed the adsorption energies of NPCZ intermediates, along with the energetics of three stepwise reactions. The initial hydrogenation step from NPCZ to 4H-NPCZ is predominantly influenced by the catalyst's acidity/basicity, whereas the subsequent deeper hydrogenation steps of 4H-NPCZ and 8H-NPCZ are governed by the d-π feedback interaction between the metal and the adsorbate. This research offers critical guidance on selecting optimal supports for Co-based catalysts in LOHC hydrogenation.
coredata.dc:title: Modulating metal-carrier interaction of high-loading Co-Al2O3-SiO2 catalysts for boosted N-propylcarbazole hydrogenation
